awd_titl_txt: NRI: Goal-Oriented, subject-Adaptive, robot-assisted Locomotor Learning (GOALL)
awd_abstract_narration:
1638007
Sergi, Fabrizio

Demand for technology to support gait training after neurological injury is increasing due to population aging. Due to recent advances in sensing, actuation, and computation, robots are ideal tools to deliver gait training, but their potential in gait neurorehabilitation has not yet been fully realized. In this context, crucial difficulties are identified in the employed control schemes, which are required to accommodate inter-individual gait variations, while promoting stable and energetically efficient gait patterns. The proposed project combines experiments with a lower limb exoskeleton with biomechanical modeling to determine subject-specific assistance strategies that enable a new approach to robot-aided gait neurorehabilitation, named GOALL (Goal-Oriented, subject Adaptive, robot-assisted Locomotor Learning). The conducted research activities have relevant applications both in rehabilitation and in human augmentation, while improving our basic understanding of gait biomechanics. The planned education and outreach components will be targeted to engage a community of graduate, undergraduate and K-12 students in topics at the intersection of robotics and biomechanics. The dissemination of the research methods and results in an open source format will benefit the robotics and biomechanics communities.

The proposed project formalizes new control methods to modulate discrete kinematic variables of gait, achieving controllability of such variables without fully constraining the gait cycle kinematics, thus promoting inter-individual variability in gait kinematics. To this aim, we pursue a systematic approach to the design of gait assistance primitives, i.e. multi-joint coordination patterns capable of modulating a chosen gait parameter, at different gait speeds. The proposed approach is based on inverse dynamics and pulsed torque approximation, and is followed by human-in-the-loop experiments to test the efficacy of assistance primitives to modulate a selected gait parameter during motor adaptation. The experimental investigation is paralleled by neuromechanical modeling of the response to robotic intervention, with the ultimate goal of generalizing the results to other gait parameters of interest for various patient populations.

por.por_cntn:
The main goal of this project was to develop new methods for training propulsion during walking in the context of post-stroke neurorehabilitation. Propulsion is a primary component of walking. The capability of generating propulsive force is essential for increasing and maintaining walking speed, which is the primary outcome measure of walking function. As such, we expect that developing training methods targeting specifically propulsion in post-stroke individuals may directly translate in improvement in walking function. Our project focused on the development of new methods for training propulsion and on the validation of their feasibility in a preclinical population.

With the support from this grant, we developed and tested two methods for training propulsion during walking.

The first developed method is based on the use of a robotic exoskeleton applying forces for a brief amount of time (100 ms) to the lower extremity during walking. First, we conducted an observational investigation using motion capture and inverse dynamics analysis to determine the optimal timing for applying such forces to modulate propulsion mechanics. Then, we used a unilateral hip-knee robotic exoskeleton to apply the forces predicted to modulate propulsion mechanics, and quantified the effects of this training mode on propulsion mechanics in healthy participants in two experiments. One experiment quantified the effect of forces applied during individual strides, and one experiment quantified the effects of a repeated application of these forces. Our results indicate that this intervention method successfully induces effects in propulsion mechanics, both during force application, and immediately after force application, suggesting that this could be a potentially beneficial method for training propulsion mechanics.

The second method tested with the support of this grant was based on the application of accelerations to the belts of a dual-belt treadmill onto which participants are walking during gait training. In our recently developed method, we accelerate the belt supporting the trailing limb during leg push-off. Accelerations require subjects to produce a greater propulsive force to counteract inertial effects, and increase trailing limb angle through increased belt velocity. We tested our protocol on healthy subjects at two acceleration magnitudes – 7 m/s2 (HA) and 2 m/s2 (LA) – and compared their results to a third control group (VC) that walked at a higher velocity during training. We collected data on 76 participants to test the hypothesis that exposure to our training program would produce after effects in propulsion mechanics and, consequently, walking speed. Results of our experiment show that the HA group significantly increased walking speed following training, while the change in walking speed in the LA and VC groups was small and not significant. Responder analysis showed that changes in push-off posture and in activation of ankle plantar-flexor muscles contributed to the greater increases in gait speed measured in the HA group compared to the LA and VC groups. The duration of after effects post training suggest that the measured changes in neuromotor coordination are consistent with use-dependent learning. Overall, the results of this study also indicates that the intervention method successfully induces effects in propulsion mechanics, both during and immediately after exposure to accelerations, suggesting that this could be a potentially beneficial method for training propulsion mechanics.

In parallel to the two main experimental studies conducted within this project, our research group has also developed new methods enabling these investigations and future research expanding the scope of these investigations.

Specifically, we have investigated the feasibility of creating subject-specific models describing the relationship between propulsion mechanics and robot intervention parameters, using gaussian process modeling, and quantified the variability of such subject-specific models. The estimated subject-specific optimal conditions have large between-subject variability in the kinetic component of propulsion mechanics (propulsive impulse). Our study suggests that individualized training may be necessary for inducing desired effects in propulsive force generation during walking.

Moreover, we have investigated the use of repetitive control (RC) to enhance force control during human-robot interaction during quasi-periodic tasks, such as those used for gait rehabilitation using exoskeletons. RC have been used before, but not in applications such as human-robot interaction, where the input from the human is not perfectly periodic, and the input period fluctuates over time. As such, we have developed different RC formulations that are robust to period fluctuations, and quantified the performance of these controllers in simulation and in experiments in a linear test bench. Our results indicate that RC can be successfully integrated in force control for human-robot interaction to improve performance beyond standard controllers, in the range of period variability expected in applications such as rehabilitation of cyclical human movements.
